definitions.definition: care that you take in order to avoid danger or mistakes; the fact of not taking any risks

examples.text: Statistics should be treated with caution.
He could find himself making enemies as well as friends unless he proceeds **with the utmost caution**.
I must stress the need for caution.
The information on the website should be treated with some caution.
The utmost caution must be exercised when handling explosives.
We urge caution in the use of this medication.

phrases: err on the side of caution

definitions.definition: a warning that is given by the police to somebody who has committed a crime that is not too serious

examples.text: As a first offender, she got off with a caution.
They let her off with a caution.

definitions.definition: a warning or a piece of advice about a possible danger or risk

examples.text: Some cautions must be mentioned—for example good tools are essential to do the job well.
Some cautions must be kept in mind when interpreting these results.
Some companies have sounded a note of caution about the outlook for the second half of this year.
The board sounded a note of caution about the economy.
I would just like to add a word of caution.

definitions.definition: to stop caring about how dangerous something might be; to start taking risks

examples.text: He threw caution to the wind and dived into the water after the child.

wordOrigin: Middle English (denoting bail or a guarantee; now chiefly Scots and US): from Latin cautio(n-), from cavere ‘take heed’.
